contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{infobox military conflict |conflict = Kerensky–Krasnov uprising |partof = [[Russian Revolution of 1917]] |date = {{OldStyleDate|8 November||26 October}}–{{OldStyleDate|13 November|1917|31 October}} | cause = [[October Revolution]] | place = [[Petrograd Governorate]] | coordinates = | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_label = | result = Defeat of Kerensky | combatant1 = {{Flagicon|Russian SFSR|1918}} [[Vladimir Lenin]], and supporters | combatant2 = {{Flagicon|Russia}} [[Alexander Kerensky]], and supporters | commander1 = | commander2 = | strength1 = ≈ 5,000 men | strength2 = 700 men (of which 600 cavalry), 12 cannons, 1 armoured vehicle }} '''Kerensky–Krasnov uprising''' was an attempt by [[Alexander Kerensky]] to regain power after the [[Bolsheviks]] overthrew his [[Russian Provisional Government|Provisional Government]] in [[Petrograd]]. Following the [[October Revolution]], Kerensky fled Petrograd and went to [[Pskov]], where he rallied troops loyal to his cause in an attempt to retake the capital. He appointed [[Pyotr Krasnov]] to lead this army. Also cadets from military schools, the so-called [[Junker mutiny]] supported Kerensky in his bid to retake control of the government. His troops successfully captured [[Tsarskoe Selo]], but the next day were defeated at [[Pulkovo Heights|Pulkovo]]. The failure of the uprising led to Kerensky being forced to go into exile, eventually finding refuge in [[France]] and later the [[United States]]. {{Russian Revolution 1917}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kerensky-Krasnov Uprising}} [[Category:Russian Revolution]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1917]] {{Russia-hist-stub}}
